>> Thanks, everyone, for coming.
I'm really excited to introduce our speaker

3.31.text:
this afternoon, Lauren Weber, author of,
"In Cheap We Trust: The story of a misunderstood

9.00.text:
American virtue.”
It seems like this book couldn't have come

12.08.text:
at a better time, as the recession has caused
Americans to reconsider their tendency to

16.88.text:
consume rather than save -- to enlarge their
debts instead of tightening the belt.

22.59.text:
Lauren begins her book talking about a different
kind of American -- her father -- who kept

27.33.text:
their Connecticut home at 50 degrees during
winters, used hand signals instead of turn

32.31.text:
signals on their car, and taught his children
how to ration toilet paper, although this

37.08.text:
last idea didn't really work out.
Lauren writes that she resented this at first,

41.67.text:
but came to understand the virtues her father
had passed down to her.

45.21.text:
Last month, she told the New York Times, "I
like the word 'cheap'. I embrace it.

49.48.text:
To me, it really means self-determination
and freedom."

52.38.text:
Lauren was a staff reporter at Reuters and
Newsday, and has written for the New York

58.12.text:
Times and the Los Angeles Times.
She currently lives in New York City.

62.22.text:
And I got to say, she really practices what
she preaches.

64.54.text:
Despite not being a local, Lauren used BART
and Caltrain to get here from the East Bay.

69.86.text:
So, no fancy car for her.
After Lauren talks and reads from the book

74.28.text:
a little bit, please feel free to come up
to the mic -- there's one mic I believe -- and

79.60.text:
ask her questions.
So please give a warm welcome to Lauren Weber.

83.87.text:
Lauren Weber: Thank you. And thanks Katie
for introducing me and for inviting me.

91.75.text:
I was telling her when my publicist sent along
the e-mail inviting me to come to Google,

97.04.text:
I was like, "Oh, my God, I feel like I've
made it.”

101.42.text:
So, some of you probably do too for being
able to work here and eat that food every

104.73.text:
day.
When I told friends I was coming, they all

107.94.text:
said, "Can you eat in the cafeteria?”
And I will report back that I did.

113.83.text:
So, thanks again for having me.
I sense from the composition of the audience

118.20.text:
that cheapness is a topic that resonates more
for men than for women maybe.

121.66.text:
[laughter] And I was also telling Katie that,
after some of the media stuff that I've done,

130.89.text:
including the New York Times -- the interview
with the Frugal Traveler Blog of the New York

135.00.text:
Times -- I have gotten a few, very random
e-mails from men proposing to me.

139.25.text:
[laughter] And usually they say -- there have
been three marriage proposals I think -- and

144.82.text:
usually they say, "Women keep breaking up
with me, because they call me too cheap.”

149.91.text:
So, they seem to hope that I could, you know,
embrace that part of them.

154.71.text:
So I'm always happy to report, to tell them
that I actually do have a boyfriend, and he's

160.26.text:
even cheaper than me.
He can't pass a dumpster without climbing

163.78.text:
into it.
So, yeah. I met him when I interviewed him

167.77.text:
for the book.
You know, we're pretty well-matched.

172.56.text:
Katie mentioned my dad -- and this is actually
the first audience that I've spoken to that

175.80.text:
didn't include at least one person who knew
my father -- and my dad did in fact, keep

182.06.text:
the heat at 50 degrees when I was growing
up in Connecticut.

184.42.text:
He is an economist.
He taught economics for 40 years at the Coast

187.88.text:
Guard Academy in New London, Connecticut.
And so, he's an economist in every sense of

192.73.text:
the word -- professionally, and then, in the
fact that he economizes on everything.

197.47.text:
He did keep the heat at 50 degrees, and I
would do my homework at the kitchen table

200.94.text:
wearing hats and scarves and with my hands
on the stove after dinner to try to keep warm.

205.60.text:
He tried to ration our family's toilet paper,
which fortunately, he couldn't figure out

211.49.text:
a way to monitor it.
So this was long before webcams.

215.26.text:
[laughter] And so, he fortunately gave up
on that one.

219.00.text:
He does, in fact, use hand signals out the
window of the car rather than using his turning

224.71.text:
signal, because I think he thinks this way,
he preserves the bulb in the light on the

229.86.text:
car.
He also insisted on washing all of our dishes

233.07.text:
by hand and he didn't use soap.
He used cold water and no soap.

238.26.text:
And eventually we figured this out and realized
this was why the knives and forks were usually

243.18.text:
encrusted with food.
You know, my dad is -- you could call him

248.04.text:
'compulsively cheap'.
So I grew up my whole life trying to figure

251.90.text:
him out.
And, like Katie said, I also complained bitterly

256.30.text:
about it.
My mother did too.

259.01.text:
In fact, while I was working on the book,
I interviewed both my parents, and I asked

262.54.text:
my mom, "How did you manage to coexist for
so long with Dad?”

266.12.text:
They're still married 44 years later.
And she said, "I should have divorced him

270.27.text:
a long time ago.”
And it turned out they had had an argument

274.02.text:
about something else that morning.
So that's partly why there was a lot of acrimony

278.24.text:
there.
But she said, "Don't tell that story.

281.00.text:
Tell the story of how I once packed all three
of you up," -- I have a brother and a sister

285.37.text:
-- "and threatened to take you all to a motel,
because the house was so cold.”

289.45.text:
And apparently, she did get us all to get
our homework into our bags and packed some

294.98.text:
clothes for school the next day.
And I think my dad at that point realized

299.14.text:
that the hotel would be more expensive; and
so, the heat went up.

304.29.text:
I did complain about this much of my childhood.
And then, when I got older -- and especially

309.47.text:
as I started to support myself -- I realized
that A, I had kind of involuntarily turned

314.89.text:
into my father.
When I moved to Seattle, I moved in with my

318.26.text:
boyfriend there, and I wouldn't let him turn
the heat above sixty degrees.

321.49.text:
So I was not quite as extreme, but I was still
a bit of a fascist about the heat.

327.93.text:
And I also found myself, you know, walking
30 blocks to save two dollars on the subway

332.59.text:
when I moved to New York.
And doing all kinds of weird things to save

337.45.text:
money.
I realized I had kind of turned into my father.

340.37.text:
And I also strangely realized that I appreciated
what he had taught me.

344.95.text:
He had given me some important lessons on
how to live within my means and on the value

350.00.text:
of doing that.
And when I was able to sort of take a step

353.66.text:
back from it, I also was able to appreciate
the fact that he is one of the most generous

357.38.text:
people I have ever known.
He gives a lot of money to charity as well

362.03.text:
as time.
He's always volunteering for a lot of different

364.75.text:
organizations he believes in.
So, he gives money to anybody who needs it.

368.08.text:
I think he has a real sense of his own good
fortune in life.

371.65.text:
And he also sent three kids to very expensive,
private universities and never uttered a word

377.52.text:
of complaint.
And, you know, what I came to realize over

381.44.text:
time was that my dad wasn't just cheap in
a crazy way.

384.91.text:
He actually really had his priorities in order
and knew what was important to him.

389.21.text:
And that he may have like gotten crazy if
you were in the shower for more than three

393.50.text:
minutes.
There would always be a knock on the door.

395.28.text:
But, you know, he really knew what his values
were.

400.08.text:
And I started to really respect that about
him.

402.55.text:
And also feel grateful that he taught me how
to live within my means.

406.92.text:
So that's kind of the personal angle to the
story.

410.91.text:
And then the other angle is that I'm a business
reporter by training -- and I worked for Reuters

417.31.text:
for a few years and then for Newsday, the
paper for Long Island -- and I was really

422.07.text:
interested in the macroeconomics of these
issues of spending and saving.

425.80.text:
I wanted to understand what it meant that
Americans had such a low savings rate, which

429.65.text:
in the last decade or so has been around two
percent.

432.99.text:
In 2005, it actually dipped into negative
territory for the first time since the Great

437.29.text:
Depression, which means Americans were spending
more than we were earning.

440.47.text:
So I wanted to understand what that meant,
what it meant that Americans had so much debt.

445.79.text:
We lived in what another historian has called,
"The age of leverage."

450.43.text:
And, you know, what the implications of all
that were.

453.74.text:
So I kind of brought both the personal side
and my professional interest to writing the

458.48.text:
book.
So that's kind of like the background for

461.97.text:
why it resonated so much for me.
And then, the moment when the idea for the

467.47.text:
book actually came to me, I was sitting on
the subway underneath Brooklyn.

471.63.text:
I live in Queens. So I was on the G Train.
Anybody here who's a New Yorker knows -- it

475.19.text:
goes between Brooklyn and Queens.
And I was reading another book.

479.97.text:
It's called "The Progress Paradox," by Gregg
Easterbrook.

482.78.text:
It's not a well-known book, but I had seen
it and was interested, because it basically

486.77.text:
asks a question, "Why if America is the most
affluent nation that's ever existed, Why are

492.27.text:
there such high levels of depression and anxiety
and unhappiness here?”

496.86.text:
And there wasn't anything in particular in
the book that sparked this question, but I

500.95.text:
suddenly looked up and thought to myself,
"What happened to thrift in America?”

504.68.text:
It seemed to me that maybe was some connection
between this hypermaterialistic culture that

510.11.text:
we live in and these very high rates of unhappiness
and depression.

516.62.text:
So that became kind of the animating question
of the book was, "What happened to thrift

521.02.text:
in America?”
You know, it used to be an important American

524.57.text:
value.
And it's a part of our national mythology

527.16.text:
of who we are and who we were.
Ben Franklin and all that.

530.13.text:
-- Did this just go off? Is it still on?
Can everybody still hear me? Okay.

536.56.text:
Yeah something just happened to the sound.
Is it back on? Okay. I think it's back on.

542.04.text:
-- So yeah. This was once an important American
value and it seemed that it was no longer

548.90.text:
a part of our sense of who we are today.
So the book has a lot of history in it and

555.18.text:
about two-thirds of it is history.
And it sort of follows this question of, "What

559.26.text:
happened to thrift in America?”
And I kind of came up with two different and

562.49.text:
almost contradictory answers.
One part of that is, On some level we actually

567.30.text:
were never a thrifty nation to begin with.
It's a myth that we've sustained about ourselves

574.20.text:
for a long time.
For most of our history, Americans were frugal

578.59.text:
because they had to be.
It was a question of necessity much more than

581.90.text:
choice.
You know, the economy was terribly unregulated.

588.12.text:
It's all based on booms and busts for much
of the 1700s and 1800s.

592.63.text:
And so, people had no choice but to live extremely
cheaply.

596.95.text:
And this was a time also when any dress you
wore was something that you had stayed up

601.61.text:
until 11 o'clock stitching by candlelight,
or any quart of firewood that you burned was

606.81.text:
wood that you yourself had gone out and cut
down.

609.53.text:
So people also had a really great appreciation
for the value of the things in their lives.

615.25.text:
Now, we live in a world where we sit on chairs.
We have no idea where they came from, or who

619.61.text:
made them.
Most of us eat food that we have no idea where

623.86.text:
it came from.
Maybe not here at Google but.

627.52.text:
And you know, so back in those days, people
were deeply connected to the resources that

632.38.text:
they used, and they had no money.
So as a result, they were probably what we

636.24.text:
would consider 'frugal' today, very resourceful,
very

639.38.text:
-- oh, it just went off again I think. There
it is. --

644.38.text:
-- very resourceful, very prudent and cautious
about spending.

647.71.text:
But, if you look at it in history, any time
Americans had more, that their incomes went

652.62.text:
up, or had more access to credit -- and that
was often really the key to it -- they spent.

658.52.text:
So, you know, I often say, "Thrift was a virtue
Americans couldn't wait to relinquish.”

662.98.text:
Whether it was installment plans in the 1850's
to buy a sewing machine, or the first credit

667.82.text:
cards in the 1950's.
As soon as Americans had greater access to

672.29.text:
cheap money, they took advantage of it.
And you know, as much as we like to think

678.83.text:
of ourselves as having been frugal back then,
often again, it was economic necessity and

683.51.text:
sometimes political necessity.
So like, during the American Revolution, there

687.59.text:
were a lot of boycots of British products.
And you know, this is where we get the tea

692.93.text:
party from -- the Boston tea party.
And there was, what I would call, "conspicuous

697.67.text:
frugality" going on back then.
Ben Franklin, Thomas Jefferson, John Adams,

702.03.text:
all those guys were trying to get Americans
to stop buying imported goods.

705.34.text:
And, you know, townspeople would get up together
and sign petitions saying that they would

709.99.text:
never drink British tea.
They called it "poison.”

712.41.text:
They would say that they would only wear homespun
 -- which was coarse textiles made in America

717.03.text:
-- rather than silks and linens from Britain
and all that.

720.69.text:
As soon as the Revolution ended, all of that
well-meaning frugality sort of went out the

726.11.text:
window, and suddenly everybody wanted Rococo
furniture from France and these British ideals

731.10.text:
of gentility where flirting was practiced
as an art and everybody wanted to have a parlor

735.77.text:
with a piano and a tea set -- were very popular.
So thrift has been a virtue Americans have

742.35.text:
sort of taken on when it's convenient and
jettisoned when it was no longer necessary.

747.32.text:
So that was one of my answers was, We were
never a particularly thrifty nation.

752.11.text:
You know, that it was not necessarily -- it
was often more of a virtue that Americans

755.97.text:
admired than aspired to.
And then, the other answer -- which may seem

760.92.text:
a little bit contradictory -- is that, we
were kind of frugal in the sense that thrift

767.52.text:
was something that we admired, but then around
the middle of the 20th century, we really

773.49.text:
developed into a consumer society and this
was not just something that happened accidentally.

778.73.text:
It was practically an orchestrated effort
after World War II.

782.95.text:
World War II -- along with being a military
effort -- was also a gigantic stimulus plan.

788.05.text:
And after the Depression, it was the war that
put people back to work and created a lot

793.23.text:
of need for factories and for production and
manufacturing and stuff like that.

798.93.text:
And even before the war ended, there were
a lot of economists and politicians who were

804.32.text:
very concerned that, once the war was over,
there would be no engine for the economy.

809.50.text:
They were really worried that we would plunge
back into a Depression -- which was a very

813.36.text:
reasonable concern.
It was a traumatic event for many Americans.

817.32.text:
So, in the early 40's, you start to sort of
get this groundswell of public propaganda

825.68.text:
about how, "Once the war's over, we got to
start buying.

829.86.text:
Now, we're using all of our metal for shrapnel
 -- for bullets and stuff -- after the war

834.26.text:
is over, it's going to be for a dishwashers.”
And advertisers used that kind of language

839.22.text:
too.
In fact, I think it's not a coincidence that

842.81.text:
Scrooge McDuck -- who is Donald Duck's miserly
uncle -- appears in 1947.

848.76.text:
And I sort of date that as around the time
that frugality went from being a virtue and

854.01.text:
something that we looked up to and championed
to being sort of a punch line.

858.54.text:
It now became funny when people saved money.
They were miserly rather than frugal.

862.90.text:
It was no longer a virtue, it was an insult
 -- a punch line, an eccentricity, or a quirk.

870.17.text:
And, you know, it was all over the culture.
Brides Magazine did a story in -- I think

875.35.text:
it was the late 40's -- saying that newlyweds
should outfit their homes with brand name

879.90.text:
goods, not only because it would make their
houses look better, but because it would keep

883.52.text:
Americans at work.
This idea that it was patriotic to spend and

887.19.text:
that it was your civic duty to be a consumer
became very widespread.

891.77.text:
And it's something that I think Americans
have really, deeply internalized.

896.22.text:
And when I was a reporter at Newsday, I covered
retail for a few years, so I was always like

901.99.text:
ambushing shoppers in the middle of their
Christmas shopping and like jumping out from

906.70.text:
behind racks of clothes to ask them like,
what they were buying and why.

910.91.text:
And I can't even count the number of times
that people would sort of sheepishly laugh

915.54.text:
and tell me they were doing their part to
help the American economy.

918.76.text:
It's just an idea that we've now taken in
deeply.

922.76.text:
So it was interesting to me to sort of track
the history of that.

926.63.text:
I'm going to read a couple of -- and one thing
I also want to add is that -- when I started

935.13.text:
working on the book, a friend of mine said
that I should call it, "Thrift: A short history

939.22.text:
of a dying virtue.”
And the more that I talked to people, the

943.29.text:
more convinced I was that it wasn't dying
at all.

945.65.text:
In fact, it was alive and well.
And there are still thousands -- and probably

949.48.text:
millions -- of people living frugally by choice.
And you know, because everybody I talked to

954.58.text:
would say, "Oh, you've got to interview my
mother.”

956.28.text:
Or "my brother", or "my boss".
Or "my daughter". Or "my husband", often.

963.43.text:
And, you know, it was clear that there are
lots and lots of people living this way.

968.27.text:
So my feeling is that thrift is alive and
well, it just kind of went underground at

973.11.text:
a certain point.
Like I said, I sort of date that to that postwar

976.60.text:
period when we started getting the message
that we needed to keep shopping, otherwise

981.36.text:
we weren't good Americans.
And of course, September 11th was sort of

984.57.text:
the apogee of that idea when both Rudy Guiliani
and George Bush and countless others got up

990.06.text:
and told Americans to go out and spend.
It was the exact opposite message that Americans

994.48.text:
received in World War II, where the whole
idea was to sacrifice.

997.09.text:
So, I'm going to read a little bit from one
of my historical chapters, and then read a

1004.13.text:
little bit from one of the later chapters.
This chapter was one of my favorites to write.

1007.30.text:
It's called "Cheap Jews and Thrifty Chinese.”
It's all about the ethnic stereotypes of cheapness.

1012.93.text:
And my family's Jewish, and I always felt
that part of the way that people looked at

1017.10.text:
my father -- as kind of an eccentric and a
nut and totally cheap -- had something to

1022.97.text:
do with him being Jewish.
That there was a particular way of combining

1028.58.text:
those two qualities in him -- the cheapness
and the Jewishness.

1032.69.text:
So this was a really fun chapter to research
and then put together.

1038.70.text:
And so I'll just read the first couple of
pages of it.

1042.96.text:
[reading] In 1885, a theater group in New
York debuted a new comic play by Frank Eugene

1048.75.text:
Chase called, 'A Ready-Made Suit.' The play
revolved around a woman who's charged with

1052.95.text:
polygamy after marrying nine men in quick
succession.

1056.44.text:
During her trial, two Jews described as 'eminent
jobbers in secondhand clothes', appear in

1061.50.text:
court to testify.
As one of them explains to the jury, they

1064.97.text:
both married the defendant on the same day,
because quote, [in a thick accent] "He thinks

1068.25.text:
if we can get one wife between us, that will
be less expensive.”

1073.34.text:
The crowd no doubt roared in appreciation
of the joke.

1076.07.text:
They certainly would have understood the subtext.
By this time, the image of the stingy, grasping

1080.54.text:
Jewish merchant or pawnbroker was a familiar
one in American popular culture -- a staple

1085.22.text:
of dime novels, variety shows, humor magazines,
and newspaper editorials.

1089.24.text:
It's one that remains with us today, hardly
dulled by age or political correctness.

1093.40.text:
For instance, there's the popular joke about
how Moses received the Ten Commandments from

1098.20.text:
God.
One day God appears to a Babylonian and says,

1101.50.text:
"I have a commandment.
I'd like to give it to you.”

1103.64.text:
The Babylonian says, "What is it?”
And God says, "Thou shalt not steal.”

1107.32.text:
The Babylonian says, "No, thanks.”
So God goes over to an Egyptian and offers

1111.85.text:
him the same deal.
When the Egyptian hears what the commandment

1114.90.text:
is, he also turns it down.
Then God meets Moses and says, "I have a commandment

1118.95.text:
for you.”
Moses says, "How much is it going to cost

1123.35.text:
"Fine" says Moses, "I'll take ten.”
[laughter] It's funny.

1128.09.text:
There are countless variations on the theme.
Why did the Jews wander in the desert for

1131.72.text:
40 years?
Because one of them dropped a nickel.

1135.80.text:
What's a Jewish dilemma? Free pork.
I think they're funny.

1139.26.text:
Jews aren't the only ethnic group to have
been branded with the Scarlet Letter, C.

1145.30.text:
Go back in history and you'll find a glut
of accusations -- often muffled in humor,

1149.16.text:
sometimes loosed with open contempt -- by
one group that its neighbors or adversaries

1153.37.text:
are cheap or miserly or obsessed with money
and accumulation.

1157.20.text:
The English viewed the Scots as hopeless cheapskates,
while the Irish were written off as drunks

1161.30.text:
and spendthrifts.
The Dutch have a long reputation for being

1164.51.text:
tight with cash.
Ben Franklin himself popularized the rhyme,

1167.89.text:
"The thrifty maxim of the wary Dutch is to
save all the money they can touch.”

1172.36.text:
In America, Yankees -- members of old families
of New England -- were both admired and reviled

1177.21.text:
for their legendary thrift.
Scandinavians, Germans, and Japanese were

1181.02.text:
tagged as parsimonious by American writers.
And Westerners used up a great deal of ink

1185.36.text:
describing the frugal ways of Chinese living
in China and abroad.

1189.92.text:
Why have so many ethnic and national groups
been cast in the role of the world's tightwads?

1194.93.text:
The late Harvard psychologist, Gordon Allport
once said that "Stereotypes are projection

1199.49.text:
screens for modern man's anxieties," and this
one is no different.

1203.84.text:
The stereotypes of cheap Jews and thrifty
Chinese -- two of the most enduring examples,

1208.18.text:
and the ones I explore in this chapter -- reveal
more about the people broadcasting them than

1212.18.text:
they do about the real lives and practices
of Jews and Chinese people.

1215.73.text:
They tell us about the social, political and
economic worries that vexed Americans as they

1220.22.text:
commiserated over a lost job with friends
or headed off to the mines for work, or spent

1225.06.text:
their week's earnings at the grocery store.
And they tell us about the complicated emotions

1229.47.text:
that hovered under the surface in a free market
economy of winners and losers.

1233.55.text:
Emotions like envy, resentment, admiration,
fear, and -- perhaps most of all -- ambivalence.

1239.71.text:
Ambivalence about the promises of equality
and opportunity and meritocracy that were

1243.62.text:
advertised as the American dream.
These emotions bobbed up and fixed themselves

1248.64.text:
to the waves of immigrants who came to the
United States in the 19th and early 20th centuries.

1253.80.text:
Native-born Americans watched Jews and Chinese
gain a fragile, economic foothold in their

1258.02.text:
adopted country and interpreted that success
as a threat to their own property and job

1262.68.text:
opportunities.
And then, I kind of go on to detail where

1266.96.text:
both of those two stereotypes kind of originated
from -- which for Jews, it had a lot to do

1273.83.text:
with being closed out of other fields, like
glass-blowing and metalwork in the Middle

1282.15.text:
Ages, and being forced into jobs like being
bankers and lenders, because Christians were

1287.39.text:
forbidden to do that.
And so, that was sort of the origins of the

1290.17.text:
Shylock stereotype.
And then, I kind of traced Shylock as he comes

1293.79.text:
to America and gets expressed in a variety
of ways here.

1297.90.text:
And then, with the Chinese -- the thrifty
Chinese -- a lot of it had to do with the

1301.83.text:
Gold Rush, and the waves of immigrants that
came from China to America and had no families

1309.79.text:
here to support and often could live on lower
incomes than a lot of the white and native-born

1315.45.text:
workers.
So there are a lot of -- there is an amazing

1319.59.text:
amount of propaganda out there in the 1800s
about how Chinese people eat rats and mice

1324.74.text:
and live on rice.
Americans couldn't get the whole like -- that

1329.37.text:
there was no giant slab of meat and potatoes
and stuff like that.

1332.97.text:
So there was a lot of talk about Chinese people
eating rats and dogs and stuff like that,

1338.83.text:
and basically like, living on lower incomes
or living on less -- sort of 'cheap Chinese

1344.25.text:
labor' idea.
But these stereotypes are incredibly potent,

1348.09.text:
and like I said, I think they stay with us
today.

1350.20.text:
Now, I have never quite been able to square
the historical development of the stereotypes

1355.53.text:
with the relatives of mine who embody them
so perfectly.

1360.49.text:
Like my 90-year-old aunt who can't leave a
restaurant without her bag being full of bread

1366.18.text:
or bread sticks or something like that.
I'm going to try not to do that.

1370.42.text:
I'm, of course, tempted to put a lot of your
food into my bag, but I'm not going to.

1377.33.text:
So the first two-thirds of the book or so
is historical and some of it is really chronological

1383.20.text:
and some of it is more thematic, like that
chapter I just read from.

1386.69.text:
And then, the last third of the book looks
more at the contemporary issues of cheapness,

1393.44.text:
you could say.
One of them really goes into the economics.

1397.58.text:
Like I said, I was really interested in what
it means that we have such a low savings rate

1400.78.text:
in this country, and you know, what the effects
from that are.

1404.81.text:
And I think we're now seeing the effects of
that -- so many people over-leveraged themselves

1409.10.text:
in the last few years, partly because the
money was free or it was cheap and easy.

1414.00.text:
And partly because we just happen -- there
are many reasons to explain our low savings

1421.91.text:
rate.
And in fact, in one interview, a TV interviewer

1425.43.text:
said to me, "Aren't Americans just fat and
lazy?”

1428.48.text:
I actually don't buy that idea.
Yes, I think probably many people could benefit

1433.60.text:
from a little more restraint and self-discipline.
But there is a whole context for why Americans

1438.55.text:
got into so much trouble, and part of that
had to do with the fact that politicians deregulated

1443.05.text:
the financial services industry in the 80's
and 90's.

1445.94.text:
That allowed banks to go through these massive
mergers and take on more risk and develop

1451.75.text:
these, you know, exotic new products like
securetizing mortgages and stuff like that.

1456.86.text:
Anyway, it all led to just a complete bubble
of cheap credit being out there.

1461.28.text:
Meanwhile, we had a political administration
that refused to provide any meaningful oversight

1467.56.text:
of this system.
And two Fed chairmen who ignored any signs

1471.87.text:
that we were in the midst of a historical
bubble.

1474.93.text:
And so, that's partly how we end up in the
situation that we find ourselves in today.

1479.14.text:
It's not just about Americans buying too many
flat screen TVs and lattes.

1482.91.text:
You know, I think there's a greater context
for it.

1485.89.text:
And in many ways, ordinary people were just
taking their cues from bankers and politicians

1490.49.text:
who didn't want the party to end.
So I do not think Americans are lazy, profligate

1497.02.text:
pigs.
Even though some people -- this particular

1501.20.text:
interviewer -- seemed to think that.
I have another chapter on the synthesis between

1505.65.text:
cheapness and the environment.
And sort of, using fewer resources and why

1510.02.text:
people like my dad were green before it became
popular to be green.

1513.67.text:
Although, he now sheepishly says that he had
no idea that there was any other benefit besides

1520.54.text:
saving money to all of his compulsive turning
off of lights and stuff.

1526.13.text:
Another chapter goes into the psychology of
cheapness.

1528.21.text:
People seem to really like that one, because
I think we all are trying to understand ourselves

1533.11.text:
and the people around us.
And the origin of that chapter came when I

1537.85.text:
asked my great aunt -- my father's aunt -- who's
a psychologist.

1541.58.text:
I said to her one day, "Why is Dad so cheap?”
And she said, "Well, Freud would say it has

1546.41.text:
something to do with unresolved potty training
issues." [laughter]

1549.45.text:
And I said, "That's ridiculous.”
And she said, "Well, it's all about what you

1552.97.text:
hold onto and what you let go of." [laughter]
And I was like, "That makes sense.” You

1557.21.text:
know?
So that kind of became the basis for that

1561.44.text:
chapter.
And then, I looked at, not only what Freud

1563.43.text:
and other psychologists said, but also behavioral
economists, who had some really interesting

1568.81.text:
-- one of my favorites was somebody told
me that, "For cheap people, the future just

1573.18.text:
feels closer.
Whereas for people who are more 'spendy' they

1577.90.text:
feel that the future is further away.”
And that made a lot of sense to me.

1580.71.text:
And I think it explains part of the way I
think, you know, when you're cheap, a lot

1585.59.text:
of it is an anxiety about what might happen
next.

1588.73.text:
And there's sort of planning for catastrophes.
And so, I think saving money has a lot to

1593.27.text:
do with creating some form of security in
the form of a nest egg or something like that.

1598.66.text:
But the chapter I'm going to read from is
called, "Living cheap in the age of mass consumption.”

1603.20.text:
Like I said, when I talked about the topic
with strangers, I'd have so many people saying,

1606.88.text:
"Oh, you know, you've got to talk to so and
so.”

1608.88.text:
Or "Interview me.”
And it became clear that lots of people were

1612.08.text:
living cheaply.
And so, I wanted, in this chapter, to investigate

1618.03.text:
some of the ways that people are living frugally
in today's America in the age of mass consumption.

1623.49.text:
And so, I followed two groups, and then, one
individual person.

1627.41.text:
The two groups were -- one was "The Compacters".
I don't know how many people here are familiar

1632.58.text:
with The Compact.
It was kind of a movement that started in

1635.30.text:
San Francisco in 2005 with eight friends who
just decided for a year they weren't going

1640.84.text:
to buy anything new.
They would buy food, they would buy medicine,

1644.51.text:
but they wouldn't buy clothes or cars or anything
that was new.

1649.00.text:
They could shop at thrift stores.
And it led to like, a lot of sharing of stuff,

1652.47.text:
you know, borrowing tools from each other.
And it became kind of a big, community-building

1656.18.text:
exercise.
And some of them have continued on -- you

1659.51.text:
know, four years later -- living this way.
But, when they started out, a reporter from

1664.90.text:
the San Francisco Chronical wrote a story
about them.

1667.31.text:
And they got hundreds of e-mails and calls
from people who wanted to join their movement,

1674.25.text:
you know?
And there was no movement; it was just eight

1676.41.text:
friends who decided to do this.
And it showed them that, like I said, there

1681.16.text:
are so many people who either were already
living this way or were craving an opportunity

1685.41.text:
to find an alternative to a consumer society
that seemed to be sort of going off the rails.

1693.59.text:
So, I did sort of an in-depth interview with
one of their founders and wrote about that.

1698.19.text:
And then, I also spent a lot of time in New
York with freegans.

1701.08.text:
Are people here familiar with freegans?
I don't know if you kind of use the same word

1704.17.text:
out here, but they're basically a band of
anticapitalist, anarchist, dumpster divers.

1709.77.text:
And they're people who try to live outside
of the money economy, they say.

1713.33.text:
They dumpster dive for their food; they squat
rather than pay rent or, you know, own homes.

1719.57.text:
They walk or bike everywhere rather than pay
for transportation.

1722.74.text:
They generally don't have jobs, although some
of them do.

1724.66.text:
There are varying degrees of it.
But I went out on a lot of trash tours, which

1731.72.text:
is how they introduce new people to freegan
ideology -- basically dumpster diving through

1736.48.text:
New York City.
There are no dumpsters in New York -- very

1739.13.text:
few.
So it basically means like sidewalk, trashpiles

1742.08.text:
of supermarkets.
You know, I thought I had been thinking about

1745.20.text:
waste and excess and cheapness for a long
time.

1748.95.text:
So I thought I was prepared for what I saw.
But I was shocked by how much perfectly good

1755.71.text:
stuff we cavalierly throw away in this culture.
We would open supermarket garbage bags and

1761.24.text:
find sealed bags of potato chips that hadn't
reached their sell-by date or anything like

1765.67.text:
that -- along with a lot of spoiled produce
and stuff like that.

1770.48.text:
You have to be pretty selective.
This is why many of them are also vegan, so

1774.07.text:
that you don't end up eating dairy or meat
or something that could actually be dangerous

1777.44.text:
for you.
So, you know, that was really shocking and

1781.65.text:
appalling to me.
And it changed the way I thought about what

1786.39.text:
we throw out in this culture and how much
of a disposable society this is.

1793.13.text:
And then, so there were the freegans.
Those were kind of the two movements I looked

1796.34.text:
at.
But then, I was really interested in people

1798.03.text:
who are just living this way on their own.
And so, the last person that I wrote about

1802.75.text:
-- and this is the section I'm going to read
 -- is one of those people.

1806.58.text:
[reading] For every person who identifies
with a political or communal form of anticonsumerrism,

1811.52.text:
there are dozens more who are solo operators.
A common thread runs through the stories of

1816.51.text:
these underspenders.
There are people who -- in the time vs. money

1821.97.text:
equation into which so much modern life can
be distilled -- choose time.

1826.23.text:
Helena Show dropped out of a well-remunerated
career in San Francisco in the mid 1990's.

1830.82.text:
Her work as a software analyst was making
her sick.

1833.57.text:
She was skinny and depressed, beset by headaches.
She arranged to take a sabbatical and travel

1838.36.text:
around Europe.
When her three months were up, she stopped

1841.10.text:
by her parent's house, sat them down and said,
"I don't want to alarm you, but I'm never

1845.05.text:
going to have a career again.”
Helena landed in New Orleans, a good place

1849.22.text:
for marginal living.
"I liked being here, where people talk about

1852.50.text:
everything except shopping and what they do
for a living," she said.

1855.59.text:
And I got the general knowledge that there
was a large population of people living on

1859.21.text:
the cheap.
From them and from trial and error, she learned

1862.65.text:
how to get by on less and less.
She found a job taking tickets at a movie

1866.37.text:
theater, and late at night, wove through the
city streets with a garbage bag full of leftover

1870.34.text:
popcorn balanced on her handle bars.
That became dinner on some nights.

1874.81.text:
Later on, she moved into an old school bus
that sat in a friend's backyard in the Lower

1878.43.text:
Ninth Ward.
She slept there for a year, paying about $60

1882.03.text:
a month and sharing the bathroom, kitchen,
and living room in the main house.

1886.05.text:
She made her own food, listened to music at
bars with no cover charge, and splurged on

1890.29.text:
a beer when she wanted to.
Now, she lives in a row of five houses whose

1894.35.text:
occupants have an informal, cooperative living
arrangement.

1897.48.text:
It's called "the chuck farm.”
They share an enormous backyard where many

1900.82.text:
of them raise food, and there's a communal
washing machine and dryer to which they all

1904.62.text:
contribute money.
"There is an art to this set of skills," Helena

1908.69.text:
said of cheap living.
We don't often think of it that way.

1912.17.text:
We're more apt to view choices like the ones
Helena has made as quirks or eccentricities.

1916.45.text:
But she's right.
It takes planning, thoughtfulness, and working

1919.34.text:
knowledge to live cheaply.
We learn a lot of those skills from the people

1922.91.text:
around us.
Helena picked up some of her values when she

1925.85.text:
decamped for France after high school and
lived with a single woman and her three children.

1929.97.text:
The woman worked in a grocery store and brought
home all of the shop's bruised vegetables

1934.03.text:
from which she cocted amazing meals.
From her, Helena saw the possibilities for

1939.83.text:
converting refuse into gold and gleaned the
value of a freezer.

1943.08.text:
Now, she freezes the excess butter and milk
she buys when they're on sale, and makes stocks

1947.02.text:
and pasta sauces in bulk when the ingredients
are cheap.

1951.39.text:
All of these activities take time.
It's what economists call 'household production'

1955.09.text:
-- the idea that we can spend time rather
than money to meet our needs.

1958.91.text:
Thrifty people are inclined to prefer the
former when they can.

1962.06.text:
And in exchange for her labor and her assiduous
attention to resources, someone like Helena

1966.65.text:
has more autonomy in her life than most people.
She now works a couple of days a week at a

1970.78.text:
store in the French Quarter, sometimes fills
in, in an art gallery, and does some gardening

1974.85.text:
work for her landlord.
But aside from those paying gigs, her time

1978.47.text:
is her own.
"I wanted to not be a prisoner of my own existence,"

1981.69.text:
she said.
"I realized pretty early on that, Any day

1984.27.text:
I was out in the street in the daytime and
not in a job, was a reason to be joyous.”

1988.31.text:
In the end, what do all of these disparate
experiments add up to?

1992.94.text:
They don't represent a unified challenge to
our consumer-driven society.

1996.58.text:
They won't topple capitalism, or perhaps even
make a dent in global warming.

2000.74.text:
What they suggest though, are new possibilities
of collective sustenance and autonomy.

2005.43.text:
In the words of Jeff Ferrell, a sociologist
who wrote a book about his own year-long experiment

2009.90.text:
in trash-picking and low-cost living.
Freegans, Compactors, and independent devotees

2014.76.text:
of cheap survival are all thinking deeply
about issues like community, sustainability,

2019.59.text:
self-determination in the contours of a meaningful
life.

2022.34.text:
They are creating alternatives to a culture
that thrives on store-bought pleasures and

2027.28.text:
disposable dreams.
They're building worlds based on imagination

2032.39.text:
I'll just stop reading there and take questions
if anybody has any.

2039.10.text:
Q So I have two questions.
The first one's easier.

2047.71.text:
What you think of advertising and its effect
on reducing frugality, because it's in the

2052.60.text:
advertiser's interest to make you buy?
And the second one, which is based on when

2057.32.text:
you said that the psychology of cheapness
is that, Stressed people are more likely to

2064.51.text:
save.
And I think it's the opposite.

2066.16.text:
People who are stressed are more likely to
buy to kind of relieve their stress.

2069.90.text:
But people who are content have nothing to
buy, you know?

2073.70.text:
They're just happy to laze about, read a book
whatever, you know?

2075.10.text:
Lauren Weber: Right.
There are many forms of anxiety.

2078.66.text:
And I think, maybe the cheap people have like
one particular form.

2081.63.text:
I'm not sure exactly how I would describe
it or explain it.

2085.65.text:
I think a lot of it is just a sort of fear
of the unknown or fear of the future drives

2090.65.text:
frugal people -- cheap people -- and it is
that sort of fear that there's a catastrophe

2095.09.text:
around the corner and you have to be prepared
for it.

2097.90.text:
In fact, thrift is sort of indirectly related
to hording.

2101.56.text:
You know, there are some famous examples of
horders whose homes got so filled with crap

2107.07.text:
that they actually died from it.
There's a famous brother -- the Collyer brothers

2111.19.text:
in Harlem in New York City in the 1940's -- there
was two brothers living.

2116.08.text:
By the time their house was excavated, the
police found like, 25 old pianos.

2123.08.text:
They found the chassis of a car in the basement.
It was just, anything that they found on the

2128.93.text:
street they would bring home.
And one of them was finally killed when a

2132.17.text:
bunch of stuff toppled on him, and he had
been taking care of his brother who then died

2140.11.text:
Psychologists have studied a lot on hording.
Very few people -- very few researchers have

2143.66.text:
studied cheapness, thrift, you know, frugality.
It's not that interesting to consumer researchers,

2149.37.text:
but it should be.
A lot of people have studied why we buy.

2152.21.text:
Very few people have studied why we don't
buy.

2158.01.text:
There's a lot of studies on hording.
And a lot of it is based on this idea that

2160.66.text:
you save every piece of string because you
might need it some day.

2163.29.text:
It's just in case.
There's that kind of 'just in case' anxiety,

2167.13.text:
which I think is related to frugal people,
cheap people.

2171.48.text:
And then, the other question on advertising.
You know, I think there's too much of it.

2177.62.text:
But I also think like, human beings are -- we're
not dopes and we're not dupes.

2182.71.text:
I think, just because you see an advertisement
doesn't mean that we're sort of programmed

2188.67.text:
to immediately go out and buy that thing.
I do think we should be trained to be better

2198.10.text:
consumers of advertising and consumers of
stuff.

2202.04.text:
And we are susceptible.
I mean, I'm susceptible too -- although I

2206.60.text:
would be hard pressed to think about what.
You know, I mean, we like brand names.

2209.95.text:
My sister and I are always calling each other,
bragging about what we found at the Salvation

2213.43.text:
Army.
So, you know, on the one hand, I do think

2217.68.text:
that stuff works and it's effective in a way
that I don't like.

2220.25.text:
On the other hand, I think human beings -- we're
not robots, you know.

2224.44.text:
We are able to resist those messages.
I wish there was more education about resisting

2231.66.text:
those messages, though.
And I hope my book is a part of that -- sort

2235.12.text:
of being able to question the imperatives
of living in a consumer society.

2239.73.text:
Q Thanks very much for being here.
In this audience, I am prepared to admit that

2245.22.text:
I am really a cheap person.
But, I think ordinarily, I kind of keep it

2249.31.text:
to myself.
If I talk to myself about it, I would say,

2254.12.text:
"I'm proud of being cheap.
I'm proud of having the value of wanting to

2257.83.text:
get value out of things.”
But on the other hand, I noticed that I don't

2262.20.text:
talk to my friends much about it.
So I'm sort of curious to know what you discovered

2265.33.text:
about the people that you interviewed -- how
they perceived themselves.

2268.68.text:
Are they proud of who they are?
Or are they proud of who they are, but they

2272.46.text:
keep it to themselves?
Any thoughts along those lines?

2275.13.text:
Lauren Weber: Right. Yeah.
I mean, all different reactions to that.

2277.50.text:
In fact, I'll just briefly read my -- the
first paragraph of the book is about that.

2282.42.text:
It says, Cheap suit, cheap date, cheap shot
 -- it's a dirty word rife with negative associations.

2288.24.text:
We hear the word 'cheap', and we think "miser,
whore, Wal-Mart, made in China, something

2292.34.text:
that's going to fall apart.”
It's an insult almost any way you look at

2296.33.text:
it.
An 84-year-old man heard about my interest

2298.52.text:
in cheapness and got so excited that he offered
himself up for an interview about his frugal

2302.62.text:
ways.
At the end of our conversation, he said sheepishly,

2305.74.text:
"Please don't use my name.
I don't want people to think I'm cheap.”

2307.84.text:
[laughter]
You know, and I did get that a lot from people

2311.62.text:
I interviewed who were uncomfortable with
the word "cheap.”

2316.06.text:
You know, they prefer "frugal" or "thrifty.”
Which is fine.

2318.29.text:
I'm probably -- before I started writing this
book would have said a similar thing, but

2322.72.text:
in the course of writing it, I started to
embrace it.

2325.00.text:
And I felt like the word itself captured some
of that ambivalence and conflict we have about

2330.02.text:
spending and saving.
I think people often use the word 'cheap'

2332.72.text:
to project.
Like my dad -- a lot of the things he does,

2335.57.text:
you could just call frugal, or whatever.
So what if he likes to buy gas at the cheapest

2340.71.text:
gas station.
But he's always been called 'cheap', and I

2344.07.text:
think people use it as an insult partly to
project to him their own discomfort with their

2349.82.text:
spending or saving habits, you know?
His brother has like no money to his name

2356.01.text:
and could learn a thing or two from my father,
and yet is always calling my dad a cheap bastard.

2360.24.text:
Yet, I think it has as much to do with comforting
himself to insult my father than about anything

2366.65.text:
my dad does.
So, you know, I kind of wanted to reclaim

2375.75.text:
Q Hi. I have a really simple question.
Is there a point where when you were doing

2384.61.text:
the book that you went, "This cheapness is
really destructive rather than a virtue?”

2388.73.text:
Lauren Weber: Yeah. Well, many points.
I mean, in my own life.

2391.68.text:
I had a terrible habit for a long time of
like, not eating lunch if I had forgotten

2396.18.text:
to make myself lunch.
And then, at the end of the day, I'd have

2398.38.text:
headaches.
You know, it was because I was agonizing about

2400.59.text:
the idea of what -- spending five dollars
on a sandwich.

2403.05.text:
That's not really doing me any good.
Finally a friend of mine said, "Do you think

2406.13.text:
you don't deserve to eat?”
And I got a little bit better about it there.

2411.16.text:
So it can become very compulsive, not wanting
to spend money.

2414.57.text:
But there's one moment that I wrote about
in the book.

2418.75.text:
While I was writing -- I've always been very
frugal, but living on a writer's income, I

2424.27.text:
had an advance, but it wasn't particularly
large at all and I went through it fairly

2428.86.text:
quickly.
And then, I was living on my savings.

2430.95.text:
And so, I found all kinds of new ways to save
money.

2433.29.text:
I started making my own laundry detergent
and, you know, friends would want to go out

2438.62.text:
and eat and I'd say, "Why don't I make a picnic?”
You know?

2440.33.text:
Because it was just cheaper to make food and
bring it for both of us.

2444.91.text:
But there was a moment where I was trying
to save money by eating some of the old food

2449.86.text:
I had in my pantry and I had this can of clams
that I'd had for like five or six years or

2455.64.text:
something.
And I decided to make like a clam sauce. So

2458.91.text:
I opened them.
I had the garlic simmering on the stove and

2462.44.text:
I opened the clams and they were kind of greenish
blue and they smelled funny, but they smelled

2468.94.text:
like cockry.
They didn't smell like foul.

2471.23.text:
And I ended up -- I went back and forth -- and
I ended up making the clam sauce.

2474.42.text:
And I was sitting there eating it while I
had my laptop open.

2477.37.text:
And I was looking up the symptoms of botulism.
[laughter] And I thought, "This is ridiculous.”

2482.02.text:
And so, I eventually did throw out the clam
sauce, but only after eating it.

2487.76.text:
-- This just went off again. Oh, now it's
on.

2491.45.text:
-- Okay so, you know, that's not good.
You know, if you don't go to the doctor because

2495.32.text:
you don't want to spend the money, that's
not good.

2497.01.text:
And then, we probably all have the friend
who never pays their fair share at dinner.

2500.80.text:
That's not the kind of cheap I like.
I like my dad's version of cheapness which

2504.95.text:
is really, personal austerity and public generosity.
He's very generous to anybody who needs it

2513.06.text:
or needs his help, but with himself, he's
monk like.

2515.60.text:
Q Hi. My whole family's three quarters of
the way through your book.

2522.64.text:
I read a couple chapters and then, when I'm
not looking, my wife steals it and reads it.

2528.43.text:
It's great so far.
I have a question around the connection between

2532.56.text:
the delay in gratification and the lack of
being cheap.

2536.91.text:
My sort of theory is that people -- if they
have 20 bucks in their pocket and they're

2541.53.text:
kind of hungry, then they're going to spend
it, because they can't delay the gratification.

2545.26.text:
And like, I know Richard Bach, I think, talks
about the "latte factor" -- that this little

2550.93.text:
thing you spend a couple bucks on lattes a
couple times a day, that adds up to thousands

2555.27.text:
of dollars by the end of the year.
So I was just wondering if you saw that threatening

2559.03.text:
your research about just people back in the
olden days took a long time to knit a coat

2563.66.text:
or to walk into town to even buy the coat.
So they wouldn't do it.

2567.76.text:
But now, you can hop on Google and buy things
instantaneously.

2571.65.text: So this lack of delay of gratification.

2573.97.text:
Lauren Weber: Yeah, that's true.
I mean, there are so many opportunities for

2576.83.text:
instant gratification everywhere.
And I think there's a lot of research now

2580.96.text:
being done on self-control as like a childhood
quality, or just a quality that can help lead

2586.61.text:
to success.
And that stuff is really interesting, because

2589.19.text:
what do you do when we live in a society where
everything is so accessible to us?

2596.29.text:
You know, whether it's alcohol or spending
 -- This just went off again -- alcohol or

2602.55.text:
spending or pornography or whatever.
It's all right there.

2606.73.text:
And there's a famous experiment from the 1960s
that a psychologist at Stanford did.

2612.53.text:
It's called the Marshmallow Experiment.
You know about it, yeah.

2617.35.text:
And it's in the book, where he gave a bunch
of two-year-olds, I think, a marshmallow and

2622.62.text:
said that if they could hold off 20 minutes,
they would get a second marshmallow.

2627.06.text:
And some of the kids just ate their marshmallow
immediately and couldn't hold off.

2630.48.text:
And some of them actually did wait and received
their second marshmallow.

2634.34.text:
It's really funny.
They waited by like singing themselves songs

2637.65.text:
or like trying to take a nap.
Very cute to me to think about these two-year-olds

2641.82.text:
trying to distract themselves from the marshmallow.
And then, they followed these kids.

2645.70.text:
And it turned out that the kids who were able
to exercise self-control did much better in

2650.77.text:
life.
They had higher SAT scores, they were much

2653.05.text:
better adjusted and stuff.
So, you know, it's interesting that many of

2660.67.text:
the kinds of addictions -- we as a society
can generally agree to look down on them -- drug

2666.59.text:
abuse, drug addiction, alcoholism, whatever.
We can mostly agree that those are bad things.

2670.76.text:
Shopping is one of the ones that we can't
agree is a bad thing.

2674.22.text:
We -- actually many people think that's a
 -- there are a lot of interests who have

2679.14.text:
something at stake in believing that having
self-control when it comes to spending money

2683.46.text:
is not necessarily good for us as a society.
So I think that's one of those areas again,

2690.03.text:
where we have a lot of ambivalence and conflicted
feelings and stuff. Yeah.

2694.64.text:
But, you know, I got the message from my father
that he judged a person's character by how

2700.28.text:
well they could deny themselves what they
wanted.

2702.38.text:
Which is partly why my sister and I, who are
very similar, are close to my dad.

2705.70.text:
And my brother, who is much more of a spendthrift
 -- he and my father have a difficult relationship.

2710.23.text:
Because my dad just, you know, doesn't have
as much respect for somebody who gratifies

2716.77.text:
Q Hi. Glad to have you here.
Do you have any estimates about like, what

2724.61.text:
percentage of the population by any definition
would cheap people consist?

2730.87.text:
And would it make sense actually for like
big marketing firms to sort of target products

2738.97.text:
for them?
Or is this like just a fringe group?

2746.37.text:
Lauren Weber: It's definitely not fringy.
There's, as I said, very few studies on people

2750.67.text:
who don't buy.
But one of the few that there is, is called

2753.40.text:
the Tightwad Spendthrift Scale.
And it was developed by three behavioral economists

2757.51.text:
at Carnegie Mellon.
And they surveyed 13,000 people and found

2763.10.text:
that about 24 percent were tightwads, you
know, cheap.

2766.84.text:
And 15 percent were spendthrifts.
Now, it's not a great sample, because almost

2772.59.text:
everybody responded to a survey that was on
the New York Times website.

2777.87.text:
And there are correllations between levels
of education and frugality.

2781.80.text:
You know, the better educated you are, the
more frugal you are likely to be.

2786.21.text:
When they did the same experiment at a shopping
mall, they kind of had the opposite numbers.

2790.62.text:
So, you know, it's hard to get a read on exactly
how many 'cheap' people are out there -- self-described

2796.34.text:
or otherwise.
But there have been stories occasionally on

2802.70.text:
companies that try to target cheap people.
And, you know, there's a lot of them out there.

2807.13.text:
Right now, Sax Fifth Avenue -- I don't know
if you have Sax out on the West Coast, but

2811.35.text:
they have this whole like, ad campaign going
on right now about 'value' and how Sax offers

2816.84.text:
value.
You know, a couple years ago, their ads were

2819.75.text:
for $5,000 handbags.
Now, it's saying like, "You need that perfect

2823.30.text:
little black suit, and it's a good deal if
it's good quality." and all that.

2827.99.text:
And in Germany -- where are you from? Okay.
In Germany, I have a friend who's German who

2833.59.text:
told me about an ad campaign for a retailer
there.

2837.39.text:
And the ad campaign was called Guisaskiel,
which means 'cheap is cool.' So some retailers

2843.54.text:
have tried to sort of co-opt this idea.
I'm not a big fan of that approach.

2847.82.text:
I'd rather cheap people stayed -- I'm not
uncorrupted.

2852.33.text:
The boots that I'm wearing right now cost
$350.

2854.33.text:
But, you know, I would like to not see cheapness
be co-opted and exploited as a marketing opportunity.

2866.98.text:
Q I don't really know where the question is
in here, but I might find it.

2873.48.text:
But, you were talking about delayed gratification
and this gentleman was as well.

2876.76.text:
It seems like there's a real joy in delayed
gratification when you get the gratification

2882.57.text:
which is much bigger than the joy that you
might get by getting something instantly.

2887.29.text:
And it really resonated with me when you talked
about you and your sister bragging in the

2891.19.text:
phone about the brand name stuff that you
got at the Goodwill. Do you find that that's

2897.02.text:
sort of a common thread in people who do delay
gratification -- that the joy of finally getting

2905.49.text:
it, or getting it after having waited an appropriate
amount of time is bigger than just going out

2910.49.text:
Lauren Weber: Yeah. Well, I find that for
myself for sure.

2912.41.text:
I mean, a lot of the interviews I did, didn't
get into like the real, sort of, psychological

2919.62.text:
workings and stuff.
And people often have a hard time articulating

2921.77.text:
that stuff anyway.
But, you know, my sister said -- she's like

2925.29.text:
me, and she's a professor.
And when she has something she needs to do

2929.93.text:
that she's dreading, she'll usually like say,
"I'll treat myself to a cookie when I'm done

2934.00.text:
writing my syllabus.” Or whatever.
And it's just -- you know, a lot of people

2936.76.text:
would just go out and get themselves a cookie
if they want it.

2938.94.text:
But to her, it's like she just thinks about
like, What kind of cookie?

2942.17.text:
And What bakery? And everything.
And I feel that way too.

2945.24.text:
I mean, I love great food, and I like to go
out to a nice restaurant, now and then, and

2950.77.text:
spend a lot of money.
But, you know, if I did that three nights

2953.45.text:
a week, I don't think I'd enjoy it nearly
as much as doing it twice a year.

2957.52.text:
So, I think that is a part of like, savoring
and experience -- when you become inured to

2963.36.text:
it if you treat yourself in those ways too
often.

2969.86.text:
Q I have a two-part question.
One is, Do you think the trend is going to

2979.96.text:
shift now, because, you know, of the recessionary
times?

2983.46.text:
And two, What do you think about government
spending?

2987.03.text:
Like, do you apply these same sort of values
to politicians, government, right?

2992.87.text:
Lauren Weber: Well, government spending.
That question comes up, because, you know,

2995.88.text:
we now are more in debt than we've ever been.
I think it's a very different thing.

3001.76.text:
The government -- I am a Keynesian at heart.
You know, I believe that the government should

3006.88.text:
prime the pump when necessary.
The government has many more levers to deal

3010.63.text:
with debt than individuals do.
The government can go into debt, but then

3013.68.text:
it can use interest rates, or tax policy,
or trade policy to mitigate the effects of

3018.99.text:
that.
When individuals go into debt, they have very

3022.30.text:
few options besides paying it off somehow,
by hook and by crook, or you know, declaring

3027.95.text:
bankruptcy.
So, I'd rather see the government spend -- you

3032.05.text:
know, I think the answer to our current problems
is not to tell ordinary people to go out and

3035.98.text:
charge up their credit cards -- I'd rather
see the government take on debt than individuals.

3041.05.text:
And then, the other question -- oh.
Where is it going? Yeah.

3042.79.text:
I mean, a lot of people are cutting back now.
It's both anecdotal and aggregate.

3047.03.text:
You hear about people canceling their cable
subscriptions or gym memberships.

3050.04.text:
You know, it's not anything like it was during
the Great Depression.

3052.83.text:
We're not at that point yet.
And it's also an aggregate evidence.

3058.23.text:
The savings rate has gone up a lot in the
last few months or so.

3061.75.text:
I think it's temporary.
You know, if you look -- there are a lot of

3064.80.text:
economists who are out there saying, "This
is a seismic shift in the American consumer.”

3068.72.text:
You know, "This is going to be permanent -- a
long-term thing.”

3072.37.text:
But if you look at the history, any time there's
been a crisis, human beings are very adaptable

3078.51.text:
and resilient.
We know how to cut back when we need to.

3081.74.text:
And then, usually as soon as the crisis passes,
consumer spending goes right back up to where

3086.29.text:
it was.
And actually goes higher.

3087.61.text:
You know, we reset our appetites a notch or
two higher than what it was.

3090.86.text:
You know, I mean, in 2001, after 9/11 and
everything, in a recession, there was a lot

3095.70.text:
of talk about, you know, "the new earnestness.”
And irony was how.

3099.58.text:
And people were going to spend less and be
more family-centered.

3103.57.text:
Well, you know, a few years later, it was
like, Hummers on the road and all that stuff.

3108.38.text:
So, yeah.
I think we'll go back to the way it was before.

3112.54.text:
The one thing that I think is different this
time around is the environment.

3115.18.text:
I think that is making people rethink the
way we consume in a different way.

3120.01.text:
So that could lead to more permanent changes
on an individual basis.

3128.11.text:
>> If there are no more questions, let's give
Lauren a big round of applause.
